;;我;;N 2015;保守党会议主办了一次关于辅助死亡的边缘会议。保守党议员基特·马尔特豪斯 (Kit Malthouse) 回忆道，观众中有三个人，其中一个是他的助手。马尔特豪斯先生沮丧地转向一位同事，告诉他他们的前景看起来很糟糕。 “不，”同事毫不畏惧地回答。 “这就是同性婚姻的开始。”

;

;协助死亡虽然仍存在争议，但在英国已不再是一个边缘问题。允许这样做的法案已经在泽西岛、马恩岛和苏格兰推进。工党领袖凯尔·斯塔默爵士公开支持修改法律。他承诺，如果他的政党如预期赢得下次选举，将在议会就该问题进行自由投票（其中<小>;议员;不会被迫遵循政党路线）。首相里希·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 的态度不那么热情，但也表示他也会留出时间来制定一项法案。; ;英国可能正处于下一次大规模社会改革的边缘。

;;
;;
;

;这并不是因为最近公众舆论发生了重大转变，而是因为已经支持了。据民意调查机构 YouGov 称，超过三分之二的英国人支持修改法律，允许某人协助绝症患者自杀（见图表）。

;

;但是有越来越多的国际证据可供参考。近年来;澳大利亚和新西兰等国家已经通过了辅助死亡法;；爱尔兰和法国也将推出类似的法案。医学观点正在发生转变。在对 2021 年的会员进行调查后，最大的医生工会英国医学协会将其立场从反对改为中立。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;政客们已经注意到了。上一次在威斯敏斯特和荷里路德的苏格兰议会对安乐死法案进行辩论时，两项法案均惨遭失败。但现在“确实感觉越来越多的同事正在寻找支持的理由，而不是反对的借口，”三月份提出新的苏格兰法案的利亚姆·麦卡瑟(Liam McCarthur)说。该法案可能会在 2025 年成为法律。

;

;很难预测威斯敏斯特的投票结果，尤其是因为选举将意味着大量新摄入;MP;。但上次举行投票时，反对安乐死的工党议员人数少于保守党议员。今年三月，“死亡尊严”运动组织发布了民意调查，显示每个选区的大多数人都支持这个问题。该组织老板 Sarah Wootton 表示，;国会议员;可能希望站在“历史正确的一边”。

;

;例如，苏格兰法案建议成年人需要身患绝症并且精神健全才有资格获得安乐死。姑息医学协会（一个反对安乐死的医生组织）的马修·多雷博士表示，尽管理论上存在针对强迫风险的保障措施，但几乎无法阻止患者选择死亡，因为他们觉得自己是一种负担。他们必须在 14 天的时间里反思自己的决定，然后再继续行动。 “你的冰箱冰柜可以获得更长的保修期。”

;

;辅助死亡的支持者认为，这种担忧仍然是假设的。俄勒冈州于 1997 年将协助死亡合法化，残疾人权利团体从未收到过任何有关强迫的投诉。在那里接受药物治疗的人中，只有三分之二真正服用过。在法律出台的第一年内;

;
;
;
;
;

;反对者还担心，鉴于国民医疗服务体系面临的压力，英国的虐待风险更大。他们指出临终关怀的质量往往是拼凑而成且资金不足，并提到了加拿大人因太穷或无法获得适当支持而接受临终关怀的故事。 “我们应该修复这个系统，而不是引入这样的想法，即这是出路，”活动组织 Care Not Killing 的阿利斯泰尔·汤普森 (Alistair Thompson) 表示。

;

;但是也有很好的反驳。在澳大利亚，安乐死法的通过是基于这样的理解：姑息治疗的资金也将增加。选择安乐死的加拿大人通常比较富有；其中超过四分之三接受姑息治疗。在英国引入安乐死的最令人信服的论据之一是，目前只有那些富有且流动性足以支付 15,000 英镑（19,000 美元）的瑞士人才能选择安乐死。

;

;事实上，一些支持者担心的是新法律会制定得太紧，而不是太松。基尔爵士在担任检察长时，对丹尼尔·詹姆斯的案件感到感动。丹尼尔·詹姆斯是一名年轻人，因一场橄榄球事故而四肢瘫痪，他的父母因陪同他前往瑞士而面临起诉。但根据拟议的苏格兰法律，詹姆斯没有资格获得安乐死，因为他的病情尚未终结。由于对安乐死的担忧，大多数保守派法律都要求患者自行服用药物。

;

;Jean Eveleigh 患有埃勒斯-当洛斯综合征，这是一种退行性病变疾病，为此她必须服用大量止痛药。她会支持任何使安乐死合法化的法案，但担心如果她遭受的痛苦太多，她就没有资格。 “我无能为力：我负担不起去瑞士的费用，”她说。英国唯一考虑为遭受难以忍受痛苦的人提供协助死亡的司法管辖区是泽西岛，该地区的公民议会建议支持该做法。

;

;立法者将还需要考虑不列颠群岛不同地区最终制定不同法律的可能性。例如，在马恩岛，一个委员会最近得出结论，其居住要求应从一年增加到五年，以阻止其他司法管辖区的人们涌入。

;

;鉴于所有这些复杂性，关于辅助死亡的适当辩论早就应该进行了。麦克阿瑟先生说，当辅助死亡法最终出台时，“我们会想知道为什么花了这么长时间”。到那一天，有些人会感到害怕。其他许多人也会松一口气。 ;■;

;;B;;英国近几十年来已成为一个更加自由的国家。根据世界价值观调查，1981 年只有 12% 的英国人认为同性恋是合理的；到 2022 年，这一数字将达到 66%。同期，接受离婚的比例从18%上升至64%。公众引领的地方，政客们也纷纷效仿：同性婚姻于 2013 年合法化；无过错离婚在 2022 年成为可能。这种模式很可能会在辅助死亡中重演。

;

;超过三分之二的英国人支持修改法律，让某人帮助绝症患者自杀。辅助死亡很有可能在不久的将来被载入法典。马恩岛、泽西岛和苏格兰的法案已经在进行中。工党领袖凯尔·斯塔默爵士对此表示同情，并;承诺免费投票;在; MP ; S中，如果他的政党赢得了下一次大选。

;
;
;
; ; ;

; >;投票，这将是明确的赞成。辅助垂死的情况是个人自由之一。英国人有权结婚他们想要的人。他们有权漫游。通过一项晦涩的中世纪法律，有些人甚至有权将绵羊穿越伦敦桥。他们应该有权选择死亡的方式和时机。更复杂的问题是应采取辅助政权的形式。这不仅是为了确保防止虐待行为，尽管它无疑必须这样做。这也是要确保法律不会太紧张。

;

;英国在许多方面都迟到了像爱尔兰和法国一样；本周向法国内阁提出了一项法案）。比利时，荷兰，俄勒冈州和瑞士已经协助了衰落的法律数十年了。自从我们辩称2015年合法化以来，有17个司法管辖区已通过了法律。尽管辅助垂死的反对者深深地持有信念，并提出了合法的关注，但这些许多司法管辖区的实际经验增强了论点的支持。

;

;对胁迫表示关注。批评家认为，没有政权能够完全保护易受伤害的人免受寻求继承的亲戚的侵害，或者实际上是在寻求削减医疗保健成本的国家。然而，证据表明，强制案件极为罕见。无论是通过社会支持还是姑息治疗，国家都应该尽最大努力帮助人们生活，但是如果不能，那些真正希望死的人不应该受苦。在辅助死亡仍然是非法的地方，只有那些有钱的人可以选择自己手中的事情 - 平均每周一个英国人前往瑞士以结束他们的生命。假设脆弱的患者的权利优先于实际上处于痛苦的人的权利。

;
;
; ; ; ;

;一些批评家说，辅助待命是“湿滑的缝隙”。如果这是您反对的基本原因，那么您几乎承认这样的原则确实有一些实例可以帮助某人死亡 - 这是问题的范围。无论如何，经验表明不存在这样的坡度。尽管比利时和荷兰的辅助死亡资格标准已扩大，但在最初的法律仅限于绝症成年人的管辖区中，他们从未这样做过。加拿大决定将助长法律推迟到精神病患病直到2027年，这表明可以按“暂停”。的确，寻求辅助死亡人数的人数正在增加：他们现在占加拿大所有死亡人数的4％，荷兰占5％。但是，如果这些较高的数字表达了人们渴望利用新自由的愿望的表达，那么这是绝对有可能通过法律而不是阻止法律的原因。

;

;无论是出于定罪还是谨慎，政客们倾向于通过编写基于俄勒冈州模式的法律来应对此类问题，该法律要求一个人在绝症中生病，而不到六个月才能生存以使其生存至少六个月有资格辅助死亡。这是爱尔兰所遵循的方法。尽管总统伊曼纽尔·马克龙（Emmanuel Macron）召集的公民议会为那些因无法治愈的疾病而难以忍受的人提供了一项更广泛的法律，但法国的辅助法案也仅限于绝症。如果以前的账单是指导，俄勒冈模板也很可能是威斯敏斯特的一个; MP ; S最终最终会辩论。它太过限制了。

;

;严格的时间限制意味着人们经常在接受致命药物之前死亡。许多人因尚未绝症的疾病而遭受痛苦。加拿大的模型使某人可以自己确定自己的痛苦是否难以忍受，这是更公平的。那里的人必须患有严重且无法治愈的疾病，并且必须等待 90 天才能反思他们的决定。认为这种更广泛的范围贬低了残疾人生命的观点是善意的，但却是家长式的。加拿大残疾人的四分之三支持现有法律。

;

;当人们是否很难确定人们是否有合理的头脑时，就会出现最荒谬的问题。因此，加拿大将辅助诊断法向精神疾病患者推迟的决定是明智的。精神痛苦与身体上的痛苦一样真实，但是社会对痛苦的理解仍然不足。医生必须能够在考虑的，理性的愿望和自杀冲动之间分辨出来，许多临床医生感到无法做到。

;

;痴呆症已经困扰着65岁以上的11名英国人，也是一个困难的领域。在痴呆症的早期阶段某人可能会提前提出辅助死亡请求，但是他们的愿望应该占上风。; ;在怀疑时，最好的经验法则不是继续。

;; T;;HE WAR; between ;Russia and Ukraine; has been catastrophic for both countries. With neither side enjoying an overwhelming advantage and their political positions completely at odds, the fighting is unlikely to end soon. One thing is clear, though: the conflict is a post-cold-war watershed that will have a profound, lasting global impact.

;

;Four main factors will influence the course of the war. The first is the level of resistance and national unity shown by Ukrainians, which has until now been extraordinary. The second is international support for Ukraine, which, though recently falling short of the country's expectations, remains broad.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The third factor is the nature of modern warfare, a contest that turns on a combination of industrial might and command, control, communications and intelligence systems. One reason Russia has struggled in this war is that it is yet to recover from the dramatic deindustrialisation it suffered after the disintegration of the Soviet Union.

;

;The final factor is information.在决策方面，弗拉基米尔·普京（Vladimir Putin）由于执政时间太长而陷入信息茧中。俄罗斯总统和他的国家安全团队无法获得准确的情报。他们所运行的系统缺乏有效的纠正错误的机制。 Their Ukrainian counterparts are more flexible and effective.

;

;In combination, these four factors make Russia's eventual defeat inevitable. In time it will be forced to withdraw from all occupied Ukrainian territories, including Crimea. Its nuclear capability is no guarantee of success. Didn't a nuclear-armed America withdraw from Korea, Vietnam and Afghanistan?

;

;Though the war has been hugely costly for Ukraine, the strength and unity of its resistance has shattered the myth that Russia is militarily invincible.乌克兰仍有可能从废墟中复活。 When the war ends, it can look forward to the possibility of joining the European Union and ;NATO;.

;

;The war is a turning-point for Russia. It has consigned Mr Putin's regime to broad international isolation.他还必须应对困难的国内政治暗流，从瓦格纳集团雇佣军和其他军队（例如别尔哥罗德）的叛乱，到俄罗斯几个地区的种族紧张局势以及最近在莫斯科发生的恐怖袭击。这些都表明俄罗斯的政治风险非常高。 Mr Putin may recently have been re-elected, but he faces all kinds of possible black-swan events.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Adding to the risks confronting Mr Putin, the war has convinced more and more former Soviet republics that Russia's imperial ambition threatens their independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity. Increasingly aware that a Russian victory is out of the question, these states are distancing themselves from Moscow in different ways, from forging economic-development policies that are less dependent on Russia to pursuing more balanced foreign policies. As a result, prospects for the Eurasian integration that Russia advocates have dimmed.

;

;The war, meanwhile, has made Europe wake up to the enormous threat that Russia's military aggression poses to the continent's security and the international order, bringing post-cold-war EU-Russia detente to an end. Many European countries have given up their illusions about Mr Putin's Russia.

;

;At the same time, the war has jolted ;NATO; out of what Emmanuel Macron, the French president, called its “brain-dead” state. With most ;NATO; countries increasing their military spending, the alliance's forward military deployment in eastern Europe has been greatly shored up. The addition of Sweden and Finland to ;NATO; highlights Mr Putin's inability to use the war to prevent the alliance's expansion.

;

;The war will also help to reshape the ;UN; Security Council. It has highlighted the body's inability to effectively assume its responsibility of maintaining world peace and regional security owing to the abuse of veto power by some permanent members. This has riled the international community, increasing the chances that reform of the Security Council will speed up. Germany, Japan, India and other countries are likely to become permanent members and the five current permanent members may lose their veto power. Without reform, the paralysis that has become the hallmark of the Security Council will lead the world to an even more dangerous place.

;

;China's relations with Russia are not fixed, and they have been affected by the events of the past two years. Russia's foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, has just visited Beijing, where he and his Chinese counterpart once again emphasised the close ties between their countries. But the trip appears to have been more diplomatic effort by Russia to show it is not alone than genuine love-in. Shrewd observers note that China's stance towards Russia has reverted from the “no limits” stance of early 2022, before the war, to the traditional principles of “non-alignment, non-confrontation and non-targeting of third parties”.

;

;Although China has not joined Western sanctions against Russia, it has not systematically violated them. It is true that China imported more than 100m tonnes of Russian oil in 2023, but that is not a great deal more than it was buying annually before the war. If China stops importing Russian oil and instead buys from elsewhere, it will undoubtedly push up international oil prices, putting huge pressure on the world economy.

;

;Since the war began China has conducted two rounds of diplomatic mediation. Success has proved elusive but no one should doubt China's desire to end this cruel war through negotiations. That wish shows that China and Russia are very different countries. Russia is seeking to subvert the existing international and regional order by means of war, whereas China wants to resolve disputes peacefully.

;

;With Russia still attacking Ukrainian military positions, critical infrastructure and cities, and possibly willing to escalate further, the chances of a Korea-style armistice look remote. In the absence of a fundamental change in Russia's political system and ideology, the conflict could become frozen. That would only allow Russia to continue to launch new wars after a respite, putting the world in even greater danger.;■;

;The next housing disaster

;;

;Global warming is coming for your home. Who will pay for the damage?

;
;
;;;
;;;;
;;

;;T;;hink about; the places vulnerable to climate change, and you might picture rice paddies in Bangladesh or low-lying islands in the Pacific.但另一个更令人惊讶的答案应该是你自己的房子。 About a tenth of the world's residential property by value is under threat from global warming—including many houses that are nowhere near the coast. From tornadoes battering midwestern American suburbs to tennis-ball-size hailstones smashing the roofs of Italian villas, the severe weather brought about by greenhouse-gas emissions is shaking the foundations of the world's most important asset class.

;

;The potential costs stem from policies designed to reduce the emissions of houses as well as from climate-related damage. ;They are enormous;. By one estimate, climate change and the fight against it could wipe out 9% of the value of the world's housing by 2050—which amounts to $25trn, not much less than America's annual ;gDP;. It is a huge bill hanging over people's lives and the global financial system. And it looks destined to trigger an almighty fight over who should pay up.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Homeowners are one candidate. But if you look at property markets today, they do not seem to be bearing the costs. House prices show little sign of adjusting to climate risk. In Miami, the subject of much worrying about rising sea levels, they have increased by four-fifths this decade, much more than the American average. Moreover, because the impact of climate change is still uncertain, many owners may not have known how much of a risk they were taking when they bought their homes.

;

;Yet if taxpayers cough up instead, they will bail out well-heeled owners and blunt helpful incentives to adapt to the looming threat.对于政府来说，分摊成本将很困难，尤其是因为他们知道选民非常关心他们的房屋价值。 The bill has three parts: paying for repairs, investing in protection and modifying houses to limit climate change.

;

;Insurers usually bear the costs of repairs after a storm destroys a roof or a fire guts a property. As the climate worsens and natural disasters become more frequent, home insurance is therefore getting more expensive. In places, it could become so dear as to cause house prices to fall; some experts warn of a “climate-insurance bubble” affecting a third of American homes. Governments must either tolerate the losses that imposes on homeowners or underwrite the risks themselves, as already happens in parts of wildfire-prone California and hurricane-prone Florida. The combined exposure of state-backed “insurers of last resort” in these two states has exploded from $160bn in 2017 to $633bn. Local politicians want to pass on the risk to the federal government, which in effect runs flood insurance today.

;

;Physical damage might be forestalled by investing in protection in properties themselves or in infrastructure. Keeping houses habitable may call for air conditioning. Few Indian homes have it, even though the country is suffering worsening heatwaves. In the Netherlands a system of dykes, ditches and pumps keeps the country dry; Tokyo has barriers to hold back floodwaters. Funding this investment is the second challenge. Should homeowners who had no idea they were at risk have to pay for, say, concrete underpinning for a subsiding house? Or is it right to protect them from such unexpected, and unevenly distributed, costs? Densely populated coastal cities, which are most in need of protection from floods, are often the crown jewels of their countries' economies and societies—just think of London, New York or Shanghai.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The last question is how to pay for domestic modifications that prevent further climate change.房屋排放量占全球能源相关排放量的 18%。许多人可能需要热泵，这种热泵与地暖或更大的散热器以及厚绝缘材料配合使用效果最好。不幸的是，改造房屋的成本很高。要求房主付款可能会引起强烈反对； last year Germany's ruling coalition tried to ban gas boilers, only to change course when voters objected to the costs.意大利采取了另一种方法，向装修的家庭提供极其慷慨但设计糟糕的救济品。 It has spent a staggering €219bn ($238bn, or 10% of its ;GDp;) on its “superbonus” scheme.

;

;The full impact of climate change is still some way off. But the sooner policymakers can resolve these questions, the better. The evidence shows that house prices react to these risks only after disaster has struck, when it is too late for preventive investments. Inertia is therefore likely to lead to nasty surprises. Housing is too important an asset to be mispriced across the economy—not least because it is so vital to the financial system.

;

;Governments will have to do their bit.直到 18 世纪，荷兰大部分地区都遵循只有附近社区才会维护堤坝的原则，结果该系统受到投资不足和不必要的洪水的困扰。仅靠政府就可以通过建设基础设施来解决此类集体行动问题，而且必须这样做，尤其是在高生产率城市周围。 Owners will need inducements to spend big sums retrofitting their homes to pollute less, which benefits everyone.

;;

;Wie het water deert

;

;At the same time, however, policymakers must be careful not to subsidise folly by offering large implicit guarantees and explicit state-backed insurance schemes. These not only pose an unacceptable risk to taxpayers, but they also weaken the incentive for people to invest in making their properties more resilient. And by suppressing insurance premiums, they do nothing to discourage people from moving to areas that are already known to be high-risk today. The omens are not good, even though the stakes are so high. For decades governments have failed to disincentivise building on floodplains.

;

;The $25trn bill will pose problems around the world. But doing nothing today will only make tomorrow more painful. For both governments and homeowners, the worst response to the housing conundrum would be to ignore it. ;■;

;;I< /span>;;n February; ;america; slapped new sanctions on Sovcomflot, a Russian state-owned shipping firm responsible for carrying around 15% of Russian oil exports to India.印度进口商几乎立即停止从 Sovcomflot 油轮接收货物。 But that did little to stem the flow of Russian crude to India, the world's third-biggest consumer of oil.与 2 月份相比，3 月份的交付​​量增加了 6%。出口商安排了前往印度的替代运输——可能是通过帮助他们绕过制裁的影子舰队。 India has also bought Russian crude at prices below the $60-per-barrel price cap imposed by the West. Taken together, these purchases have helped make India the second-biggest importer of Russian oil, behind China.

;

;The immediate impact has been to help India to meet demand at a lower cost. In 2023 nearly 90% of India's oil consumption was sourced from abroad. Roughly 34% of those imports came from Russia. The discount on Russian crude has narrowed over time, from 20% at the start of last year to around 5% in December, but it still yields significant savings on India's oil imports, which were worth $181bn last year, around 27% of the country's total import bill.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Cheaper imports have helped India's Bharatiya Janata Party (;BJP;) government. On the government's instructions, oil firms kept the prices of petrol and diesel unchanged in 2022, even as global oil prices surged in the aftermath of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The price freeze helped insulate India from the type of fuel inflation that ravaged neighbouring Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Last month, with an eye on the upcoming general election, retailers cut petrol and diesel prices for the first time since the war began. Less costly oil has also given the ;BJP; more fiscal room by shrinking the fuel-subsidy bill. That has helped it extend a popular subsidy for liquefied petroleum gas by a year.

;

;Globally, Indian buying of Russian oil has been important. It has helped prevent a supply crunch. India's petroleum ministry claims that global oil prices could have shot up by about $30-40 per barrel were it not for India's trade with Russia. On April 4th an American official visiting Delhi encouraged India's imports of discounted Russian oil, as it was important to “keep oil supply on the market” while ensuring the Kremlin's profits were being hit.

;

;India has also rewired energy markets by processing Russian crude and shipping it back to the West.欧洲国家主导了对俄罗斯的制裁，但仍与俄罗斯石油保持联系。 In 2023 they imported roughly 225,000 barrels per day (b/d) of Indian petrol and diesel products, up from an average of 120,000 b/d in the previous five years, according to the International Energy Agency (;IEA;）。 These exports have boosted India's trade balance and are another illustration of India's growing clout in the market. In 2023 oil-related exports were worth $85bn, around 60% more than in 2021.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;India's influence on global oil markets will only increase. The ;IEA; expects India to be the single largest source of growth in global demand between 2023 and 2030. Growth and urbanisation are expected to drive oil consumption up by 20% by 2030, to roughly 1.2m barrels per day, accounting for more than a third of the projected global increase. To meet the boom in demand, Indian refineries are expected to increase processing capacity faster than any country in the world besides China.

;

;Much of the oil will have to come from abroad.印度石油储备的产量正在下降。 It accounted for just 13% of the country's supply in 2023. An import-dependent strategy is always vulnerable to risks, such as a wider conflict in the Middle East.

;

;Ultimately, the most powerful way to reduce India's oil imports is to reduce demand for the stuff itself. In last year's budget India allocated $2.6bn towards programmes in green sectors.但与智囊团能源、环境与水理事会估计印度要在 2070 年实现净零排放（正如其承诺的那样）相比，这只是小巫见大巫。 ;■;

;然而，保险业高管虽然很伤心，但并不感到惊讶。气候变化使此类事件变得更加常见。从 2000 年到 2009 年的十年间，仅 3 次雷暴就给该行业造成了超过 10 亿美元的损失（按当前价格计算）。从2010年到2019年，有十个。自 2020 年以来，已有 6 个。再保险公司瑞士再保险公司表示，此类风暴目前占保险业因自然灾害造成的损失的四分之一以上。在不以极端天气闻名的欧洲，过去三年每年的损失已超过 50 亿美元。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;气候变化正在对世界各地的财产造成巨大损害，而且并不总是在人们想象的地方或方式。飓风、野火和洪水变得越来越常见和严重，但更常见的祸害也是如此。例如，在伦敦，夏季热浪期间，城市大部分地区的粘土干燥导致意外沉降，给房主带来巨额账单。阿姆斯特丹也面临着类似的问题，那里的许多老建筑都建在插入沼泽土壤的木桩上，而不是传统的地基上。夏季持续的干旱导致地下水位下降，使堆积物干燥并暴露在空气中。这使得桩腐烂，促使上面的建筑物下垂。不幸的房主可能需要承担 100,000 欧元（108,000 美元）或更多的补救工作费用。除了气候变化给房主带来的昂贵维修费用之外，政府还可能迫使他们安装低碳供暖和制冷设备，或者提高房屋的能源效率，从而进一步增加他们的成本。

;钱坑

;

;结果是业主面临巨额账单。考虑到气候和政府政策的不确定性，估计必然是模糊的。但编制金融指数的摩根士丹利资本国际 (MSCI) 认为，未来 25 年，气候变化造成的成本，无论是财产损失还是减排投资，可能几乎达到全球气候变化成本的十分之一。机构投资者投资组合中的住房价值。如果整个住房市场也是如此，那么世界将面临大约 25 万亿美元的打击。

;

;即将到来的账单是如此巨大，在事实上，这不仅会对个人繁荣产生严峻影响，也会对金融体系产生严峻影响。房地产是世界上最重要的资产类别，估计占全球财富的三分之二。房屋是世界上许多最重要的金融市场的核心，抵押贷款充当货币市场的抵押品并支撑银行的资产负债表。如果风险的大小突然下降，借款人和贷款人都意识到支撑如此多交易的抵押品并不像他们想象的那么值钱，一波重新定价的浪潮将在金融市场产生反响。由于房主强烈要求昂贵的救助，政府财政也将受到影响。简而言之，气候变化可能会引发下一次全球房地产崩盘。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;目前气候变化的风险并没有在房价中得到适当的体现。 《自然》杂志的一项研究发现，如果仅考虑洪水增加带来的预期损失，美国房屋价值将下降 1,210 亿至 2,370 亿美元。许多买家和卖家根本没有意识到其中的风险。当这些东西带回家时，价格会发生变化。 《城市经济学杂志》2018 年发表的一项研究发现，2012 年桑迪飓风造成大面积洪水之后，纽约洪泛平原上建造的房屋价格持续下跌 8%。加利福尼亚州要求卖家披露野火风险的区域，其价格比这些区域外的房屋低约 4%。

;

;在许多情况下气候变化对房地产造成的风险只是慢慢变得明显——就像伦敦的地质情况一样。这座城市的许多房屋所用的独特的黄色砖块都是由房屋所在的粘土制成的。它很好用，但最近证明不太好用。在现在气候温和的冬季，降雨量较多，因为温暖的空气可以容纳更多的水分。当粘土吸收雨水时，它会膨胀。温暖的夏季会再次干燥，导致地面收缩。结构工程师欧文·布鲁克表示，如果膨胀和收缩均匀，那就不成问题。但由于树木会吸收附近的水分，因此它们并非如此。由此产生的手风琴效果变化会导致地面在某些地方弯曲和扭曲，上面的房屋会倾斜和破裂。

;;
;;
;

;根据英国地质调查局的数据，到 2030 年，伦敦五分之二的住房（180 万套住房）将容易发生沉降。牛津和剑桥等其他附近城市也面临风险（见地图）。通常通过安装混凝土基础进行修复，通常成本约为 10,000 英镑（12,500 美元），但也可能更高。咨询公司 ;P;w;C; 估计，到 2030 年，英国家庭保险公司每年将支付 19 亿英镑的沉降索赔费用。“说实话，保险公司会这样做布鲁克先生说道。

;

;分析师将气候变化的直接影响称为“收缩” -膨胀”效应，身体风险。有些，例如收缩-膨胀，是慢性的。其他则是严重的，例如飓风、洪水和野火。在任何一种情况下，房屋不仅可能被完全摧毁，而且此类灾难持续存在的风险也可能导致在同一地点重建房屋变得危险。即使是最简单的天气变化也会使房屋无法居住：只有一小部分印度家庭装有空调，因此如果温度大幅上升，许多家庭就会变得热得难以忍受。

;
; ;
;

;各地的人身风险都在增长（参见图表 1）。这个问题不仅限于欧洲干燥、多雷的夏季。根据政府机构国家环境信息中心的数据，美国去年遭受了 28 起自然灾害，造成的损失超过 10 亿美元，超过了 2020 年 22 起自然灾害的记录。与此同时，台风多克苏里袭击了菲律宾，随后袭击了中国南部去年，这是历史上损失最惨重的台风。

;

;但是，风险分布并不均匀。英国央行在 2022 年进行的研究发现，如果全球平均气温比之前高出 3.3°C，那么只有 10% 的邮政编码区（每个区大约有一个小镇大小）将占抵押贷款受损的 45%。工业水平，很大程度上是因为这些地方洪水风险增加。出于类似原因，粗略计算表明，阿姆斯特丹大约 40% 的房产价值可能会因物理风险而消失，而东京的这一比例仅为 7%。

;

;关于对较贫穷国家的影响的数据最为稀少，但世界上许多人口最多的城市都位于沿海。慈善机构基督教援助会 (Christian Aid) 2017 年发表的一项研究表明，就人口而言，印度加尔各答和孟买以及孟加拉国达卡最容易受到海平面上升的影响。就面临风险的财产价值而言，最脆弱的是迈阿密、广州和纽约。

;

;东京上涨

;

;但风险并不固定。它们是可以减少的，最明显的是通过私人和公共努力改善准备工作。东京面临的风险较低，部分原因在于 1966 年台风杰特袭击后，东京显着改善了排水和防洪能力，淹没了 42,000 栋建筑物。 2017 年兰台风带来类似降雨量时，只有 35 栋建筑物被淹没。

;

;理论上，房价和保险价格应该提供明确的数据有关气候相关损害对任何特定财产的风险的市场信号。但即使在明显存在危险的地方，例如迈阿密，信号也经常失真。一方面，佛罗里达州立法机关直到三月份才批准了一项法案，要求出售房产的人披露该房产之前是否曾被洪水淹没。更糟糕的是，有充分的理由认为佛罗里达州的家庭保险价格过低。大多数佛罗里达人都会对这样的想法感到惊讶：根据保险公司 Insurify 的数据，该州典型单户住宅的平均年保费今年可能会达到 11,759 美元。然而，即使费率如此波动，近年来仍有几家私人家庭保险公司破产或退出佛罗里达州。

;
;
;

;然而，州政府通过国有最后保险公司来保护房主免受市场影响，该保险公司为房主提供政策私人保险公司不承保的房屋。公民财产保险公司已成为佛罗里达州最大的房屋保险公司（见图 2）。目前其风险敞口为 4,230 亿美元，远高于该州的公共债务，而且全部都针对房屋，根据定义，其他保险公司认为风险太大而无法承保。这表明公民一直在向纳税人提供大量补贴。联邦政府承保的洪水保险也存在类似的缺陷。第一街基金会旨在追踪气候变化对美国财产的威胁，该基金会计算出，如果业主必须支付真实的保险费用，西棕榈滩（迈阿密海岸上的一座繁华城市）的房屋价值将下降 40%抵御飓风和洪水。这将耗尽许多房主的资产，并导致大量抵押贷款没有足够的抵押品。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;然而，迈阿密的房地产市场正在蓬勃发展。一座座公寓楼在城市周围拔地而起。根据 Case-Shiller 指数，过去五年房价上涨了 79%。如果市场正在向房地产发出有关气候变化风险的任何信号，那就是放松。

;

;更糟糕的是，物理风险并不是气候变化给业主带来的唯一危险。还有“转型风险”，指政府可能会迫使房主以减少其房产碳足迹的方式进行翻修。此类政策可能会导致巨大的成本。例如，德国联合政府原计划从今年年初开始禁止安装新的燃气锅炉，这将使许多房主承担 15,000 欧元或更多的费用，即使在享受补贴之后也是如此。 （该政策引起了轩然大波，以至于去年这些变化被淡化并推迟。）

;

;如果政府坚持其排放目标，代价高昂任务授权将会回归。建筑物排放量占全球能源相关排放量的 18%，主要是通过冬季供暖和夏季制冷产生的。监管机构国际能源署估计，到 2030 年，建筑能源效率和清洁技术每年需要投资 5,740 亿美元，是 2023 年投资 2,500 亿美元的两倍多。环境政策还会提高电费，增加房主的负担。成本以不同的方式。

;
;;
;

;量化转型风险很棘手。 ;MSCI; 的布莱恩·里德 (Bryan Reid) 表示，很难知道世界上有多少住宅物业，更不用说绿色政策如何影响其价值了。他的公司的模型表明，如果政府实施旨在将气温上升幅度限制在长期平均水平以上 1.5°C 以内的政策，那么成本将达到投资组合中持有的住房价值的 3.4%。这低于 ;MSCI; 模型显示的物理风险所造成的 6% 的损失，但仍然很大。

;

;从长远来看从长远来看，实体风险和转型风险很可能都会落在政府身上。压力团体环境保护基金会的卡罗琳·苏斯基想象了这样一种场景：多种自然灾害同时袭击美国不同地区。这可能导致全国大部分地区的保险价格突然上涨以及房地产价值下滑。不愿意花一大笔钱继续住在灾区的房主可能只是将房屋钥匙交还给抵押贷款提供商，而抵押贷款提供商可能会因价格下跌而面临损失。

;

;美国国家支持的抵押贷款巨头房利美 (Fannie Mae) 和房地美 (Freddie Mac) 要求借款人购买房屋保险。如果他们的客户无力承担，这两家公司可能会遭受一波违约潮。 “我们敏锐地意识到了这一点，”负责监管房利美和房地美的联邦住房金融局代理幕僚长丹·科茨说。他补充道：“有很多权宜之计，可以防止一连串的不良事件产生我们都担心的后果。”他指出，联邦救灾款项以及房利美和房地美在疫情期间向房主提供的宽容可能会重复。 covid-19大流行。但这些措施实际上会将风险从房主转移到联邦政府。

;

;抵押未来

;

;在大多数选民拥有自己房屋的民主国家，政客们有动力尽可能长时间地保护房主免受气候变化法案的影响。德国联合政府一直在努力从燃气锅炉的争端中恢复过来，这被认为是一个警示故事。拖延也反映了气候变化的全球逻辑：即使政府在本国采取严格的减排措施，也不一定会减少全球排放，从而减少实体风险。例如，无论对德国家庭的能源效率进行多少投资，也无法阻止 2021 年造成超过 400 亿美元损失的洪水。

;While the European Union and its member countries have contributed considerably to Ukraine's budget and humanitarian needs , America has been Ukraine's largest provider of military aid, amounting to $44bn since Russia's invasion in February 2022. But further help has been stuck for months. In October 2023 President Joe Biden proposed that Congress appropriate $60bn for Ukraine as part of a security bill that would have spent a further $45bn on securing America's southern border and on arming allies like Israel and Taiwan.

;Six months of congressional ;Sturm und Drang; ensued, but nothing has come to the president's desk.俄克拉荷马州的一位共和党参议员詹姆斯·兰克福德(James Lankford)花了几个月的时间就南部边境问题进行了强硬妥协的谈判，以配合援助计划，但他自己的政党在二月份公布该计划后三天内就将其破坏了，因为唐纳德·特朗普(Donald Trump)该党的假定总统候选人拒绝了该法案，因为拜登先生在选举年获胜。 The Senate then passed a $95bn aid bill without any border provisions, which Mr Johnson then rejected and refused to bring up for a vote.

;

;When foreign policy is subordinated to domestic politics, as has happened with Ukraine and Israel, incoherence often follows. You can see this in the short history of Mr Johnson's own pronouncements. Before he was appointed speaker, Mr Johnson was a Trump-following Ukraine-sceptic, voting against a small $300m military-aid bill in September 2023. In October, after getting the top job, he sounded more supportive, saying that Vladimir Putin must not win. In December he said that this necessary aid must be paired with sweeping reforms to Mr Biden's border policy, which would be his “hill to die on”. In February, when Mr Biden announced plans to secure the border through executive action after the failure of the bipartisan Senate deal, Mr Johnson denounced them as “election-year gimmicks”—despite having previously called for him to do exactly that. In March he said that he would unveil a new plan for Ukraine aid after Easter.

;

;The eggs have stopped rolling, but Mr Johnson is yet to release his plan, the details of which are not being shared widely. Many of the rumoured components are designed to mollify the isolationists in his party: aid to Ukraine would be labelled as a forgivable loan rather than direct aid (following a suggestion of Mr Trump's); some of the funding would be recouped by seizing Russian assets that are currently frozen (though many more of these are in the ;EU; than the ;US;); and Mr Biden would have to endure a poke in the eye by overturning his recently announced moratorium on new export projects for liquefied natural gas.

;Democrats might grumpily accept even the environmental回滚; the real hindrance to Mr Johnson will be his own party. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican congresswoman from Georgia, has filed a “motion to vacate” Mr Johnson from his leadership, were he to secure Ukraine funding by relying on Democratic support. Ms Greene is probably the most Putin-friendly member of the party—bizarrely saying in a radio interview this week that Ukraine was attacking Christianity while Russia was “protecting it”—but the Republican majority is razor-thin, meaning that a few defectors could cast off Mr Johnson.

;

;Some think that Mr Johnson might simply have to accept that he cannot both arm Ukraine and keep his job. “Then he'll go down in history as being a profile in courage who does the right thing. We need Winston Churchills right now, not [Neville] Chamberlains,” says Don Bacon, a Republican congressman representing Nebraska. Mr Bacon has been a staunch supporter of Ukraine funding, crafting a so-called discharge petition which could circumvent the speaker and bring a bill directly to the floor for a vote if a majority of House members were to sign on. The discharge petition, which has been closely watched by anxious European diplomats in Washington, is an unconventional parliamentary tool. It is still a long shot, but its existence gives Mr Johnson at least some leverage with his own hardliners.

;

;Critics like Ms Greene are unlikely to be placated. But the cost of congressional dithering is in this case quite real. Last week Sergei Shoigu, Russia's defence minister, announced that his army had captured 400 square kilometres of territory from the Ukrainians, who have been forced to conserve ammunition (Ukraine is over 600,000 square kilometeres, but the trend is not good). Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine's president, has said that “if the Congress doesn't help Ukraine, Ukraine will lose the war.” ;■;

;在富裕的世界中，对儿童的跨性别护理方法现在分为三大类：Laissez-Faire，Draconian，Draconian和谨慎。自由放任的做法在美国的蓝色州很常见，它认为，如果孩子们认为自己是异性，并且迫切希望调整自己的身体以适应这种感觉，那么应该允许他们这样做。支持者说，如果拒绝这种“性别肯定护理”，他们的生活将受到破坏，他们可能会考虑结束这种生活。一些活动人士用强硬的语言补充说，只有跨性别者才可能反对。 The American Academy of Pediatrics, a national body, supports the provision of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones to minors, while evaluating new evidence.

;The draconian approach is that such treatments should simply be banned.这在美国的红色州很常见，一些政客煽动对跨性别者的反感以赢得选票。一些州将禁止治疗与对提供治疗的医生的严厉处罚结合起来。佛罗里达州威胁要判处他们五年监禁； Idaho, ten. Texas has tried to investigate whether parents who seek such care for their children are fit to be parents;尽管这件事现在已经在法庭上解决了。 In all, 22 American states have outlawed or restricted transgender care for adolescents, most of them recently.

;

;The cautious approach, which informs policy in Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden and now England, stresses that more evidence is needed.没有人知道为什么在过去十年中被认定为跨性别者的儿童数量激增。在给他们服用可以使他们永久不育且无法体验性高潮的药物之前，医生应该探索其他干预措施。许多跨性别认同的孩子后来放弃了，有时意识到自己是同性恋。许多人还患有抑郁症或患有自闭症。卫生保健提供者应该就这些问题提供咨询，即使孩子需要，也不要急于采取更具侵入性的治疗。 Thus, the ;NHS; in England now offers puberty blockers only as part of a clinical trial. Cross-sex hormones should be provided only to children over 16, and with “extreme caution”, says the Cass Review.

;As ;The Economist; has ;argued before;, the cautious approach is the wisest.跨性别者应始终受到尊重和善意对待，成年人应该可以自由地对自己的身体做出决定。但正如卡斯博士总结的那样，必须防止“未经证实的方法渗透到临床实践中”。在一个政治争议如此激烈的领域，这可能很难。在卫生系统中，这也可能更加困难，因为私人医生每次干预都会获得报酬，因此有动力满足患者的要求。 Nonetheless, it is the responsibility of medical authorities to offer treatments based on solid evidence. ;■;
